reviewText: Are there words that can deliver to anyone's ear,  the impact of this film?  I don't think so.  I cried and I laughed and I wondered, what if it had been me?  This was a stirring way to deliver the true tale of barbarism on the part of one set of people and survival and strength of another set of people.  I thank those who put money up to make this film.  I thank those who participated in telling their stories.  I thank the man who started this journey, thus allowing us to know these particular women's  narrative, both the horror they experienced and how they come through it to have rich lives afterward. They do not speak of their lives afterward, but you can tell that they love life and are grateful and appreciative that they lived.  I felt the strength of peace that is in each of them now, in the present, even as they related their history. Very poignant. Thank you. Although I wish this had never happened to anyone, it is better to be the victim of Evil than to be the perpetrator of Evil.  Bless these beautiful women.  Bless all who perished and all who survived this Evil time in our history.

This is one of the most poignant statement on life in the Nazi concentration camps of eastern Europe I have ever seen. Auschwitz-Birkenau was the infamous place and the narratives are those of six very special Jewish women who survived the horrors of the holocaust by some incredible examples of courage, ingenuity, and intuition. This documentary takes the viewer inside the daily existence of a regimen meant to exhaust, destroy, exploit, and demean the human spirit. Each women interviewed here found her purpose to survive the countless beatings, tortures, deprivations and heartbreaks by learning to help others cope with their own helplessness and not yielding to terror. Each story is accompanied by pictures that graphically reinforce the gruesome and unhappy details as if they had happened yesterday. This presentation is definitely a celebration of life in the midst of death, disease, evil and apocalyptic terror. What kept people alive during this ordeal had to be their ability to dream and long for better days. The memories here, while haunting, appalling, and still very raw, only enhance the moral stature of these six women and countless others as true heroes of modern history. There is an instructive irony in those words "Work Makes You Free" that confronted millions of inmates as they walked through the gates of this hellhole decades ago. As one of the interviewees mentioned, what doesn't kill you truly makes you stronger.

Film included graphic pictures, very authentic, very chilling.  However, I felt this film was a showcase for photographs rather than the actual HOW these women survived.  What did each person do to make herself needed and, therefore, safe from the ovens? They spoke eloquently and were interesting to listen to, but I have heard other stories of the things that individuals did which, while not savory, were safety nets.  The women spoke of mental attitudes which held them up but not of any physical actions which might have had the same purpose.  Only one woman did this when she talked about her dressmaking designs and how those designs were noticed (admired?) by a captor. And, what happened when one woman went for a swim in the pool? We did not hear a result of her actions.  I did not want gory details of what people did to ingratiate themselves --- the photographs were gory enough --- but it seems to me to be an interesting topic as to what did those prisoners actually endured to save themselves on a more personal basis.  I understand sharing food, blankets, etc., but those were humanitarian and commendable actions --- there must be something more that each person did.  Maybe it's just me. I found the title misleading, so I postponed watching this excellent documentary for some time. It is a 57 minute documentary about a variety of women from different backgrounds and countries and their personal journey surviving the Holocaust. SPOILER ALERT - Only one reference is made to swimming in the German's pool. I never saw the theme of the title in the story.

I found the facts about the different country's cultures and populations interesting. I was not aware that Hungary was basically anti-Semetic. I was shocked to learn of the statistics regarding survival rates among women and children. Most of all, it was educational and uplifting. Hearing the lilting laughter and the authentic accounts delivered in such a neutral manner was refreshing. I am so glad these brave women learned what they needed to do to survive, and emerged knowing that their attitude and acceptance was a key to making it out alive. Mostly I was struck by the amount of gratitude they had for EVERYTHING that was presented to them. This film helped me shift my attitude to one of empowering myself to keep on. The ending was a little weak. I went back to the beginning to remember who was from what country and what family. Did they know each other at Aushchwitz? It would add to the documentary to see which family members survived, and where are they or their surviving family members now? I have often heard that gratitude is the attitude for success. They are living proof. I hope they continue to remember the wonderful part of their lives and let the horrible events evaporate from their memories. Impossible, yes, but these women seem to have created a healing within themselves. They also reminded me of how important it is to be with others that one can call a 'family'. My mother, the last member of my family, recently passed away. I am now inspired to keep on, and create a new family, and joy is a choice we can all choose.
